Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209C.proposition: Jurisdiction: This Court is the proper forum pursuant to the Massachusetts Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction and Enforcement Act (UCCJEA), Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209C, and the Probate and Family Court’s general jurisdiction over custody matters.

Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).proposition: (General authorities and authorities commonly cited in Massachusetts custody modification and child safety matters; Plaintiff requests that the Court consider these statutes and cases as applicable and appropriate.)
Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).support_reasoning: Troxel is a U.S. Supreme Court substantive due process case about parental rights and third‑party visitation, not a Massachusetts case or a custody-modification decision. However, Massachusetts courts and practitioners do commonly cite Troxel as a general authority on the constitutional dimension of parental rights, the presumption that fit parents act in their children’s best interests, and limits on state interference in child‑rearing. In that broad, background sense—as a general authority relevant to custody/child‑safety disputes—it is an appropriate citation, though it does not address Massachusetts statutes or standards specifically.
Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “In light of this extensive precedent, it cannot now be doubted that the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment protects the fundamental right of parents to make decisions concerning the care, custody, and control of their children. … Accordingly, so long as a parent adequately cares for his or her children (i.e., is fit), there will normally be no reason for the State to inject itself into the private realm of the family to further question the ability of that parent to make the best decisions concerning the rearing of that parent’s children.”

Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745 (1982).proposition: (General authorities and authorities commonly cited in Massachusetts custody modification and child safety matters; Plaintiff requests that the Court consider these statutes and cases as applicable and appropriate.)
Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745 (1982).support_reasoning: The proposition describes Santosky as a general authority commonly cited in custody modification and child safety matters, to be considered as applicable where appropriate. Santosky is a leading U.S. Supreme Court case on due process protections and the required standard of proof in proceedings to terminate parental rights, emphasizing the fundamental liberty interest in the parent-child relationship. It is therefore appropriately cited as a general authority on constitutional protections in serious child protection and custody‐related proceedings, including in Massachusetts practice.
Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The fundamental liberty interest of natural parents in the care, custody, and management of their child does not evaporate simply because they have not been model parents or have lost temporary custody of their child to the State. … When the State moves to destroy weakened familial bonds, it must provide the parents with fundamentally fair procedures. … [B]efore a State may sever completely and irrevocably the rights of parents in their natural child, due process requires that the State support its allegations by at least clear and convincing evidence.”

In re Marriage of LaMusga, 32 Cal. 4th 1.raw_text: In re Marriage of LaMusga, 32 Cal. 4th 1072 (2004)
